flightCancellation.heroTitle: Flight Cancellation Compensation in USA & EU

summary.p1: Air travel can occasionally encounter turbulence, and unforeseen flight cancellations can disrupt your plans. However, you may be entitled to substantial compensation, potentially up to ‚Ç¨600, for flight cancellations in accordance with EU regulations.
summary.p2: In this guide we cover the key rules on canceled flight compensation, who is eligible, how much you can get, and how to file your claim.
summary.p3: For flights within the US, there is generally no law that requires airlines to pay cash compensation for cancellations. Airlines must still provide refunds or rebooking options depending on your situation, and you may be covered by other regional rules if your trip involves international routes.

rules.title: What are the rules on compensation for canceled flights?
rules.p1: When it comes to air travel to and from Europe, passengers are entitled to specific rights in cases of flight cancellations. EC 261 is the main regulation and, if the airline cancels your flight, you may be able to file a claim and receive up to ‚Ç¨600.
rules.note1: In general, you may qualify if:
rules.li1: Your flight was going to take off in the EU (flights to the EU also qualify in some cases).
rules.li2: The airline notified you of the cancellation less than 14 days before departure.
rules.li3: If you took a replacement flight, your new arrival time was significantly different to your original flight (see exact times below).
rules.li4: The cancellation occurred within the last 3 years.
rules.li5: You had a confirmed reservation (booking confirmation with flight number and passenger names).
rules.li6: The reason for the cancellation was within the airline's control (e.g. operational circumstances, technical difficulties, or airline staff strikes).
rules.note2: Canceled Flight? You may be entitled to as much as ‚Ç¨600 in canceled flight compensation (EU).
rules.subtitle: When was your flight canceled?
rules.more14: More than 14 days notice: No compensation this time.
rules.less14: Less than 14 days notice: You could get up to ‚Ç¨600 compensation from your airline.

entitlements.title: Canceled Flight Compensation: What Are You Entitled To If Your Flight Is Canceled?
entitlements.p1: When your flight is canceled, the airline must offer you a choice: an alternative flight (re-routing) or a refund. If the cancellation happens within 14 days of departure, you may also be entitled to compensation.
entitlements.subtitle1: Flight Canceled: Compensation, Flight Refund, or Re-routing
entitlements.note1: EC 261 requires the airline to offer three choices:
entitlements.li1: A full or partial refund of your original ticket ‚Äî and a return flight to your original point of departure if needed.
entitlements.li2: The earliest possible alternative transport to your final destination.
entitlements.li3: A new ticket to your final destination at a later date of your choosing, subject to availability.
entitlements.re1: If you haven't taken any portion of your flight, you get a full refund.
entitlements.re2: If you have already departed, you can get a refund for the unused portion of your ticket.
entitlements.re3: If the trip no longer serves your travel plan due to the cancellation, you can also get a refund for the used portion.
entitlements.re4: Whenever relevant, the airline must provide a return flight to the first point of departure.
entitlements.re5: EC 261 says you must be reimbursed within 7 days.
entitlements.altP: Your airline must provide a new way to reach your final destination as soon as possible, under comparable transport conditions.
entitlements.subtitleConvenient: Alternative on a convenient date for you
entitlements.convP: You can choose to take alternative transport on a later date you select (subject to availability). The alternative must still be under comparable conditions.
entitlements.destNote: Note about your final destination: If an airline flies you to a different airport, it must pay to transfer you to the original airport (or a nearby address if you agree).
entitlements.subtitleOther: Flight Cancellation Compensation: Other Entitlements Under EC 261
entitlements.careP: When you‚Äôre stuck waiting for the airline to get you back on track, you‚Äôre entitled to necessary assistance from the airline depending on your situation.
entitlements.careLi1: Meals and refreshments during your wait.
entitlements.careLi2: Access to communications, including two telephone calls, telefax or fax messages, and emails.
entitlements.careLi3: If you need overnight accommodation, a hotel room plus transport to and from the airport.
entitlements.upLi1: If you are placed in a higher class on an alternative flight, the carrier cannot charge you any extra payment.
entitlements.upLi2: If you are placed in a lower class, you can get a reimbursement of 30‚Äì75% of the price you originally paid.
entitlements.informP: You have the right to be informed about the content of EC 261. Airlines must display information on passengers‚Äô rights at their check-in counters at every airport where they operate.
entitlements.furtherP: Your right to compensation under EC 261 does not affect your right to request further compensation (except where passengers have voluntarily surrendered their reservations). If you do claim further compensation, the EC 261 amount may be deducted from any additional compensation you receive.

eligibility.title: Are You Entitled to Compensation for a Canceled Flight?
eligibility.subtitleDef: Canceled Flight Compensation: Definition of flight cancellation
eligibility.defP: A flight is officially considered canceled when it never takes off. EC 261 defines a canceled flight as ‚Äúthe non-operation of a flight which was previously planned and on which at least one seat was reserved.‚Äù
eligibility.extP: Airlines do not owe compensation if they can show the cancellation was caused by ‚Äúextraordinary circumstances‚Äù outside their control. Examples include lightning strikes, medical emergencies, serious adverse weather, acts of sabotage or terrorism.
eligibility.extNote: The European Court of Justice has repeatedly stated that ‚Äútechnical difficulties‚Äù and ‚Äúoperational circumstances‚Äù don't qualify as extraordinary circumstances. Strikes by flight staff are generally not considered extraordinary.
eligibility.connP: Eligibility for connecting-flight cancellations depends on your itinerary, airline, which segment was canceled, and whether everything was booked under one reservation. In general, if the itinerary was one booking and your journey began in Europe (or arrived in Europe on an EU carrier), EC 261 protections may apply to the whole trip.

where.title: Where EC 261 Applies
where.p1: EC 261 applies based on route and carrier, not your nationality. The scope includes EU countries, EEA countries (Iceland, Norway), Switzerland, and outermost regions (Canary Islands, Madeira, Azores, and more).

faq.title: Common questions about flight cancellation compensation
faq.q1: Am I entitled to compensation for a canceled flight?
faq.a1: Yes, if the cancellation was within the airline's control and you were notified less than 14 days before departure.
faq.q2: Can I claim compensation if my flight was canceled due to weather?
faq.a2: Generally no, weather is an 'extraordinary circumstance'. But if other flights designated for the same route were operating, you might have a case.
faq.q3: Can you get money back when you cancel a flight?
faq.a3: If you cancel, the refund depends on your ticket rules. If the airline cancels, you are entitled to a full refund or re-routing.
faq.q4: How long after a canceled flight can I claim compensation?
faq.a4: It varies by country (e.g., 3 years in Germany, 6 in UK, 5 in France/Spain).
faq.q5: How much compensation can I claim for a canceled flight?
faq.a5: Up to ‚Ç¨600, depending on the flight distance and the notice period given.
faq.q6: How to claim compensation for canceled flight?
faq.a6: You can contact the airline directly, hire a lawyer, or use a specialized service like FlyCompense.
faq.q7: My flight was canceled and the airline offered me a new ticket. Can I refuse the ticket?
faq.a7: Yes. You can refuse the re-routing and choose a full refund instead if you decide not to travel.
faq.q8: What do I do if the airline cancels my flight and does not reply to me, or only offers me a voucher?
faq.a8: You are entitled to cash compensation or a monetary refund. Insist on it. Vouchers are optional.
faq.q9: If my flight is canceled before take off, am I entitled to flight cancellation compensation or a flight cancellation refund?
faq.a9: Both, potentially. You always get a choice of refund or re-routing. You get additional compensation if the notice was short and the cause was not extraordinary.
faq.q10: Can I get compensation for a canceled flight in the US?
faq.a10: US laws don't mandate compensation for cancellations, only for denied boarding. However, you are entitled to a refund if you choose not to travel.
faq.q11: Can I still get compensation for UK flights after Brexit?
faq.a11: Yes. The UK has incorporated EC 261 into UK law (UK 261). Your rights are largely the same.

missedConnection.heroTitle: Missed connection compensation: how to claim your rights

summary.p1: Missing a connecting flight is a nightmare setback on a long journey. But if you were traveling to or from Europe you might be protected by regulation EC 261.
summary.p2: If you miss a connecting flight due to flight delay, cancellation, or being denied boarding, you could be entitled to up to ‚Ç¨600 compensation.
summary.note: If you missed a connecting flight because of delay, cancellation or overbooking you could be eligible for up to ‚Ç¨600 in compensation.

eligibility.title: Airline Compensation for Missed Flights: Are You Eligible?
eligibility.note1: You can claim EC 261 compensation for a missed flight connection if‚Ä¶
eligibility.li1: You missed the connection due to a flight delay, flight cancellation or overbooked flight.
eligibility.li2: In the case of delay: your missed connection caused you to be over three hours late arriving at your final destination.
eligibility.li3: Your connecting flights were part of the same booking, not purchased individually.
eligibility.li4: The flight took off in the EU (from any airline) or landed in the EU (provided the airline is headquartered in the EU).
eligibility.li5: The disruption was within the airline's control (e.g. airline staff strike or technical difficulties).
eligibility.li6: You did not miss your connection for a reason under your control (e.g. late at gate or incorrect documentation).
eligibility.li7: You encountered these problems on a flight operated no more than three years ago.
eligibility.li8: It doesn't matter whether the airline has already provided you with a replacement flight.
eligibility.note2: The simplest way to find out if you are owed compensation is to use an eligibility checker.
eligibility.subtitleRes: How to tell if your connecting flights were part of the same reservation
eligibility.resP: Missed connections are only eligible where both flights were part of the same reservation. That means you booked a single journey and received a ticket for connecting flights.
eligibility.resNote: A simple check: if the booking reference number is the same for all flights, they are considered part of the same reservation.
eligibility.subtitleWhere: EU flight compensation connecting flights: where EC 261 applies
eligibility.whereP: EC 261 applies to all passengers on flights within Europe regardless of nationality. It covers flights departing Europe, and flights landing in Europe on a European airline.
eligibility.row1: From inside the EU to inside the EU
eligibility.row2: From inside the EU to outside the EU
eligibility.row3: From outside the EU to inside the EU
eligibility.row4: From outside the EU to outside the EU
eligibility.noUnless: No - unless your journey originated in EU*
eligibility.itinNote1: * If flights were purchased under one booking, EC 261 considers them part of the same journey. Journeys departing the EU are generally covered regardless of where disruption occurs.
eligibility.itinNote2: EC 261 also applies in Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and outermost regions.
eligibility.covP: Under EC 261, passengers are eligible to claim compensation when airline fault causes one of these disruptions:
eligibility.covLi1: A 3-hour (or more) delayed arrival at your final destination
eligibility.subtitleNotCovered: Missed connections which are not covered
eligibility.extP: Extraordinary circumstances are events outside the airline's control (lightning strikes, medical emergencies, air traffic control strikes, serious adverse weather, acts of sabotage, political unrest, terrorism, etc.).
eligibility.strikeNote: Airline strikes do not fall under extraordinary circumstances.
eligibility.strikeP: EU courts have ruled that internal strikes by flight staff are generally not ‚Äúextraordinary circumstances‚Äù, so airlines must compensate when a strike is to blame.
eligibility.personalNote: Missed connections for personal reasons are not covered.
eligibility.personalP: If you are responsible for missing the connection (late at gate, missing documents, etc.) you will not be entitled to compensation under EC 261.
eligibility.busP: Even if you're on a business trip, it is still you (the passenger) who is entitled to compensation, not the person who paid for the ticket.

amount.distP: When claiming compensation for a missed connection, it is the total length of the journey that matters, not the leg you missed.

rights.title: What Are Your Rights Regarding Airline Compensation for Missed Flights?
rights.subtitleEC261: EU flight compensation for connecting flights: EC 261
rights.ecP1: If you missed your connection due to the fault of the airline, the airline should rebook you on the next available flight to your destination.
rights.ecP2: If the missed connection means the trip no longer serves your travel plan, you may also use your right of reimbursement. This applies if a flight is delayed five hours or more, canceled, or you are denied boarding.
rights.ecNote: You may ask the airline for a return flight to the first point of departure AND a refund for the journey not made. Refunds must also include parts already made if the trip no longer serves its original purpose.
rights.careP1: After several hours of delay, your airline must provide meals and refreshments and access to communications (two telephone calls, fax messages, or emails).
rights.careP2: If overnight accommodation becomes necessary, they must provide a hotel room and transportation to and from the airport.
rights.reimbP: If your delay exceeds five hours, you are entitled to a full or partial refund of your original ticket and a return flight to your point of departure, if needed ‚Äî in addition to compensation.
rights.upP: Your new flight should be of a similar standard. If you are offered an upgrade, the airline can't charge extra. If downgraded, you can get 30‚Äì75% reimbursement of the price you paid.
rights.furtherP: Compensation under EC 261 doesn't affect your right to request further compensation, though the EC 261 amount may be deducted from additional compensation.

faq.q2: How can I avoid missing a connecting flight?

summary.title: Flight Cancellation Refund - Your Rights
summary.p1: When you take an EU flight and it‚Äôs disrupted, you‚Äôre often entitled to money back from the airline. But if you‚Äôre confused about whether to ask for a flight refund under EC 261, or whether to demand compensation, we have good news for you. In some cases, you might be entitled to both.
summary.p2: Here‚Äôs the difference: If you can no longer take the flight, EU law says you have the right to a full flight refund. But, depending on the reason for the disruption, you might also be entitled to compensation, to make up for the inconvenience.

entitled.title: When are you entitled for a flight refund or flight compensation?
entitled.h3Refund: When can you get a refund on plane tickets?
entitled.noteRefund: You are entitled to a flight refund if:
entitled.li1: If your flight was delayed by more than 5 hours, and you no longer want to take the flight.
entitled.li2: OR If your flight was canceled less than 14 days before departure, and the alternative flight offered doesn't serve your original travel plans.
entitled.li3: OR If you have been denied boarding but you don't want to take the alternative flight offered.
entitled.p1: According to EC 261, you have the right to a flight cancellation refund if your flight has been canceled. You will be offered an alternative flight, and you can request a different alternative if you prefer. But if none of the available flights suit your travel plans, you can request a full refund.
entitled.p2: The same goes for a flight delay refund ‚Äì if your flight was delayed by more than 5 hours, you have the right to decide not to take your flight, and ask for a refund. This is because a five-hour delay is just as inconvenient as a total cancellation.
entitled.h3Comp: When can you get a compensation?
entitled.noteComp: Regardless of the refund, you are entitled to flight compensation if:
entitled.compLi1: Your flight was delayed for 3 hours or more.
entitled.compLi2: OR Your flight was canceled less than 14 days before it was due to depart.
entitled.compLi3: OR You were denied boarding due to overbooking.
entitled.compLi4: AND Your flight was set to depart from the EU or was on an EU airline arriving in the EU.
entitled.compLi5: AND You had a confirmed flight reservation.
entitled.compLi6: AND Your flight disruption occurred in the last 3 years.
entitled.compLi7: AND The reason for the flight disruption was within the airline's control.

cancellation.title: Flight Cancellation Refund - Your Rights
cancellation.h3Can: Can I get a flight cancellation refund?
cancellation.p1: A flight cancellation refund is just one of the options available to you in the event that your flight was canceled less than 14 days before your departure. According to EC 261, all canceled flights are entitled to either a:
cancellation.li1: Full or partial refund of your ticket, with a return flight to your original departure point if needed.
cancellation.li2: Earliest possible alternative transport to your final destination.
cancellation.li3: A new ticket to your final destination at a later date of your choosing.
cancellation.p2: If you choose to get your flight refunded, the airline must send reimbursement within 7 days. It must be paid in cash, by means of electronic bank transfer, bank orders, or bank checks.
cancellation.p3: Alternatively, airlines can also offer compensation by means of travel vouchers or other services, but only by signed agreement of the passenger. If you want to receive your refund in cash, always check what documents you are signing before accepting any vouchers!
cancellation.p4: If you have not yet departed, you will be refunded the full cost of your ticket. However, if you have already departed, it gets a bit more complex.
cancellation.li4: Generally, you can get a partial refund for the unused portion of your ticket.
cancellation.li5: If the alternative flight offered to you no longer serves your original travel plan, you can demand a full refund (including the used portion).
cancellation.li6: If needed, the airline must also provide you with a return flight to the first point of departure.
cancellation.h3Add: What are additional compensation for canceled flights?
cancellation.addP1: Passengers can receive both a refund of an airline ticket and compensation for the cancellation, provided that their flight qualifies for compensation.
cancellation.addP2: To qualify, the airline must have let you know about the flight cancellation less than 14 days before it was due to depart. There are some other factors to take into account ‚Äì whether they are able to offer you a very similar replacement for example.

cancellation.h3NotEntitled: Which situations are not entitled to compensation?
cancellation.notEntP1: Not all flights qualify for compensation. If you were informed about the cancellation or delay at least 14 days or more before your departure, your flight does not qualify for compensation.
cancellation.notEntP2: According to EC 261, if the disruption is caused by ‚Äòextraordinary circumstances‚Äô, the airlines are not obligated to pay. Extraordinary circumstances are events that are beyond the airline‚Äôs control. This includes:
cancellation.extraLi1: Strikes initiated by airport employees or air traffic control
cancellation.notEntNote: Remember: even if the airline is not responsible for the disruption, you still have the right to a flight refund and to receive care.

delay.title: Flight Delay Refunds - Your Rights
delay.h3Can: Can I get a refund for a delayed flight?
delay.p1: An extensively delayed flight inconveniences a customer just as much as a canceled flight. You have the right to get a refund if your flight was delayed by more than 5 hours.
delay.p2: After you have been waiting that long, you can choose to abandon your flight rather than continue to wait. At that point you are entitled to a full refund if you have yet to travel, or a partial refund if you have already flown part of the route.
delay.p3: If you can show that because of the delay, the flight no longer works for the purpose that you booked it for ‚Äì for example you will be too late to attend a business meeting ‚Äì you can ask for a full refund, including parts of the ticket you have flown. You can also ask for a ticket back to your original departure point if needed.
delay.p4: As with a canceled flight, your refund must be paid in cash within 7 days by means of electronic bank transfer, bank orders, or bank checks.

delay.addP1: As with cancellations, passengers can receive both a refund and compensation for a flight delay, provided that their flight qualifies.
delay.addP2: The threshold for compensation for delayed flights is 3 hours, so lower than the 5 hour-delay threshold for flight refunds.

changes.title: Flight Changes and Refunds
changes.p1: There are times when you need to make a change to your flight, or perhaps you can‚Äôt travel at all and need a refund. Airlines will usually charge a fee if you try to change your flight, but there are some exceptions and some ways around the fees.

sectionCompensation.title: Air passenger regulations about compensation
sectionCompensation.p1: Strong air passenger rights mean travelers can claim compensation for the inconvenience and stress of flight delays, cancellations, and overbookings.
sectionCompensation.subtitle: Compensation amounts
sectionCompensation.p2: Compensation for flight disruptions serves multiple purposes.
sectionCompensation.p3: For you, it recognises the inconvenience of a flight disruption, and helps to make amends.
sectionCompensation.p4: But compensation also holds airlines to account, and incentivises them to avoid unnecessary disruptions.

accordions.noCompContent: One thing that many regulations have in common is that airlines do not have to pay compensation for delays and cancellations caused by extraordinary circumstances or force majeure. Extraordinary circumstances usually means situations outside of the airlines' control. For example sudden strikes by air traffic control, or freak weather.
accordions.diffTitle: What's the difference between compensation and refunds?
accordions.diffContent: Working out what money you are entitled to after a flight delay or cancellation is even more confusing because you may be owed several different things: Refund (money you paid and later get back), Compensation (money to make amends for a problem or inconvenience), and Reimbursements (if you had to spend extra money because of a delay). In some situations you are entitled to all three!
accordions.accommodationContent: If you have to wait overnight for an alternative flight, most laws require the airline to put you up in a hotel and provide transport to and from the airport.
accordions.foodContent: Many passenger rights say that airlines must provide refreshments if your flight is delayed by more than a few hours. The exact time varies depending on your regulation and flight distance.
accordions.infoContent: Airlines have to tell you your rights if there is a flight cancellation, a delay of at least two hours, or if boarding is denied. They should give you a written notice setting out the rules for compensation and assistance.
accordions.rebookingContent: When flights are cancelled, passengers are entitled to choose between a full refund or an alternative flight to their destination. The airline cannot force you to accept vouchers instead of cash.
accordions.baggageContent: If your luggage is lost, damaged, or delayed, you may be entitled to compensation under the Montreal Convention or local regulations. Keep all receipts for essential purchases made while waiting for delayed baggage.
accordions.accessibilityContent: Airlines must provide assistance to passengers with reduced mobility or disabilities. This includes help at the airport and during the flight, as well as ensuring wheelchairs and mobility equipment are handled carefully.
accordions.tarmacContent: Some regulations require airlines to provide water, food, and access to bathrooms if passengers are stuck on the tarmac for extended periods. In the US, planes cannot remain on the tarmac for more than 3 hours (domestic) or 4 hours (international) without allowing passengers to deplane.
accordions.feesContent: Recently, air passenger rights have started tackling extra airline fees. For example Canada's regulation says that children under 14 must be sat next to their parent or guardian for free. Airlines cannot charge them to sit together.

sectionCountries.title: Which countries have passenger rights?
sectionCountries.p1: Unfortunately not all countries have air passenger rights. Here's the most useful to know about.
sectionCountries.h3: Air passenger rights and regulations you should know
sectionCountries.p2: There are several regional or international laws that serve as powerful tools to air passengers. These include, but are not limited to, EU legislation EC 261, various US laws, Brazil's ANAC 400, and the Montreal Convention.
sectionCountries.p3: Certain regulations have a wider reach or prove more advantageous than others. However, it's best to remember that disrupted flight circumstances can differ significantly, and it's helpful to know which strengths you can rely on for your journey.

legalAccordions.strikeTitle: Airline staff strikes are eligible for compensation
legalAccordions.strikeContent: Courts have ruled that passengers are entitled to compensation for disruptions resulting from airline staff strikes. Staff strikes are not an extraordinary circumstance, bringing much-needed assistance to the thousands of passengers affected by strikes every year.
legalAccordions.earlierTitle: You get compensation if your flight is rescheduled for earlier
legalAccordions.earlierContent: Courts have ruled that passengers get compensation for flights that were rescheduled by 1 hour earlier or more. Flights that leave an hour earlier than scheduled cause just as much inconvenience to a passenger as a canceled flight does.
legalAccordions.multiLegTitle: You get compensation for the whole route on multi-leg flights
legalAccordions.multiLegContent: If your multi-leg flight had a delay on any leg, you are entitled to compensation for the whole route. It is irrelevant which leg is affected; compensation is due for the entire journey.
legalAccordions.missedContent: A delay of the first leg that leads to the passenger not having the minimum connection time to change planes is automatically considered the airline's fault. You don't need to prove anything beyond the delay.
legalAccordions.refuseTitle: You still get compensation if you refuse re-routing
legalAccordions.refuseContent: Passengers don't have to accept the re-routing schedule offered by the airline following the cancellation of their flight. If you decide not to fly at all, you are still entitled to compensation.
legalAccordions.infantContent: Infants are now eligible for compensation, even when the parents only paid a fee for taking the baby with them on the aircraft.

faq.q1: Can I claim if the airline that I flew with has gone bust?
faq.a1: If the airline that you flew with has gone bankrupt or otherwise no longer exists, you are not likely to receive your compensation even if you do submit a claim. Passengers usually are last in a long list of creditors. However, if your flight was operated by another airline, it is possible to claim compensation with them instead.
faq.q2: The airline is offering to reschedule my flight. What does this mean?
faq.a2: Airlines will offer to reschedule your flight if there has been a delay or disruption. They will usually offer you a new flight schedule, or in some cases, offer an entirely new replacement flight. You can accept or reject and seek refunds/compensation when covered.
faq.q3: Can I get compensation for a codeshare flight?
faq.a3: If your disrupted flight meets the necessary criteria ‚Äî then yes. For codeshare flights, the airline who is operating your flight at the time of cancellation or delay is the one responsible for paying compensation.
faq.q4: How long do I have to file a claim?
faq.a4: The right to claim compensation does eventually expire under most laws, but the time limit varies. Some countries and laws only give you a few months to file a claim, others up to 10 years. Typically up to 3 years for EU claims; UK claims can be made up to 6 years after the flight.
faq.q5: Can I get compensation if my flight was part of a package holiday?
faq.a5: Yes. If your flight is delayed or canceled and meets the necessary criteria, you can claim for compensation from the airline. It is the airline's responsibility to compensate their passengers, so the laws apply even if the flight ticket was part of a package holiday.
faq.q6: Can I claim compensation if I booked via an online travel agent (OTA)?
faq.a6: Yes, if it meets the necessary criteria. You can claim compensation for any flight delayed by 3 hours or more, or if your flight was canceled less than 14 days before departure, and if your airline was considered at fault.
faq.q7: When am I allowed to claim extra costs due to a flight disruption?
faq.a7: You can claim unexpected expenses up to 2 years after a flight delay or cancellation if the costs incurred were a direct result of the disruption. This covers food and drinks, hotel bookings, and transport tickets.
faq.q8: Who pays for my food and lodging if I have to wait several days?
faq.a8: The airline is always responsible for providing you with care in case of lengthy delay or cancellation. They must provide you with food and lodging, transport to and from the airport, and access to communication.
faq.q9: What do I do if my replacement flight was downgraded?
faq.a9: Under EC 261, if your flight was canceled and the replacement flight downgrades your seats (e.g. business class to economy class), you can get reimbursed between 30% ‚Äì 75% of the ticket price you originally paid.
faq.q10: How can I protect my future flights against delays and cancellations?
faq.a10: You can protect any future flights by purchasing travel insurance. Additionally, keep all booking confirmations, boarding passes, and receipts. Know your rights before you fly.
faq.q11: Who can help me if the airline doesn't pay my compensation?
faq.a11: If an airline refuses to pay your compensation, the next step is to take them to court. Thankfully, if you claim with FlyCompense, we handle all the legal procedures for you. We operate on a no win, no fee policy.

assistance.title: How to request special assistance
assistance.p1: Many laws give you the right to ‚Äúspecial assistance‚Äù ‚Äî a service provided by airlines and airports to ensure passengers with disabilities or reduced mobility can travel with dignity from departure to arrival.
assistance.p2: That could include airport wheelchair assistance or other mobility help, but can also include support for the elderly and travelers with service dogs.
assistance.note1: There‚Äôs no universal rule for requesting special assistance.
assistance.p3: Most laws require an accessible way to request it when you book your flight (via a tour operator or directly with the airline).
assistance.note2: To get the best possible support, plan ahead.
assistance.p4: Some countries specify limits (e.g. UK often requires 48 hours notice; Brazil sometimes 72 hours). In the US, airlines may not ask for advance notice unless your request requires significant planning.
assistance.note3: Our advice: plan as early as possible.

regulations.title: Regulations around the world
regulations.intro: There are a number of laws around the world protecting your rights as a passenger with a disability, reduced mobility, or additional needs. Here are some of the main ones.

us.title: United States
us.li1: Covers disabled passengers and passengers traveling with service animals
us.li2: Applies on flights to, from, or within the US
us.p: The ACAA makes it illegal for airlines to discriminate against passengers with disabilities and requires airlines to accommodate passenger needs. It is enforced by the US Department of Transportation.

uk.title: United Kingdom
uk.note: Equality Act 2010 & the Civil Aviation Regulations 2014
uk.li1: Covers disabled passengers, the elderly, and those with social communication and interaction difficulties
uk.li2: Applies on flights to/from UK airports on UK- or EU-registered airlines, and flights from outside the UK or EU to the EU on UK carriers
uk.p: In the UK, disabled passengers have the right to free assistance suitable to their needs at the airport and on board the aircraft. Disabilities do not need to be permanent or apparent to benefit.

eu.title: European Union
eu.li1: Covers passengers with disabilities, passengers traveling with assistance dogs, and people with reduced mobility (including the elderly, pregnant women, and those traveling with small children)
eu.li2: Applies on flights within the EU
eu.p: EC 1107/2006 states that passengers with disabilities or reduced mobility should have access to air services comparable to other citizens, and have the same right to free movement, freedom of choice, and non-discrimination.

canada.title: Canada
canada.note: Accessible Transportation for Persons with Disabilities Regulations (ATPDR)
canada.li1: Covers passengers who are disabled, requiring assistive devices, or service animals
canada.li2: Applies on flights to, from, or within Canada
canada.p: The Canadian Transportation Agency protects the rights of people with disabilities to accessible transportation. These regulations aim to ensure barrier-free access and require airlines/airports to provide a range of services.

brazil.title: Brazil
brazil.li1: Covers passengers who are disabled, over 60, pregnant/breastfeeding, have reduced mobility, or travel with young children
brazil.li2: Applies on flights departing or arriving in Brazil
brazil.p: Brazil grants the right to special assistance and treats passengers needing assistance as priority passengers (e.g. priority boarding and priority support when disruptions occur).

It‚Äôs typically free and can apply to passengers with disabilities, reduced mobility, additional needs, service animals, the elderly, and sometimes pregnant travelers.

faq.a2: Contact either the airport or the airline and ask what types of special assistance they can provide.

faq.a5: In Brazil, Canada, the EU, the UK, and the US, assistive devices like wheelchairs should be handled with care and transported free of charge. When possible they should be stowed in the cabin; otherwise, in the hold and returned to you at the aircraft door.
faq.note5: In the US, additional protections under the ACAA provide compensation if your equipment is damaged.
faq.q6: How do I get to my seat on the plane?
faq.a6: Airlines should provide free assistance to help you reach your seat (e.g. lift or aisle wheelchair). If flying with a low-cost airline that doesn‚Äôt use jet bridges, contact both the airline and airports to ensure assistance is arranged.

essentiel.title: EC Regulation 261/2004: What you need to know for compensation
essentiel.p1: Regulation EC 261/2004 protects your passenger rights in the European Union. It covers flight delays, cancellations, and overbooking.
essentiel.p2: You can claim up to ‚Ç¨600 in compensation, depending on your situation.
essentiel.p3: Traveling can quickly become frustrating when things don't go as planned. Fortunately, Regulation EC 261/2004, also known as EU 261, is there to protect your rights and compensate you when your flight is cancelled, overbooked, or boarding is denied.
essentiel.p4: A flight delay of more than 3 hours may also entitle you to compensation, provided the airline is responsible.

takeaways.title: Regulation EC 261/2004: Key Takeaways
takeaways.label: In Short
takeaways.li1: Airlines must compensate you for cancellations, delays over 3 hours, or denied boarding when they are responsible for the disruption.
takeaways.li2: Compensation ranges from ‚Ç¨250 to ‚Ç¨600 per person, depending on flight distance. These amounts are set by law: the airline cannot offer you less.
takeaways.li3: Regulation EC 261 applies to all flights departing from the EU, as well as flights arriving in the EU operated by an EU airline. Arrivals operated by non-EU airlines are not covered.
takeaways.li4: If you have to wait, you have a right to care from the airline: meals, drinks, hotel accommodation, and transport to/from the airport if necessary.

whatIs.title: What is Regulation EC 261/2004?
whatIs.p1: Regulation (EC) No 261/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 February 2004 protects air passengers and establishes compensation conditions for travel disruptions. It holds airlines financially accountable, unless the disruption was caused by extraordinary circumstances outside their control.
whatIs.p2: Regulation EC 261/2004 is one of the most comprehensive legislations in the field. This regulation plays a vital role in defending passenger rights for all travelers departing from a European airport, regardless of their nationality. In certain circumstances, passengers traveling to Europe from non-EU destinations may also be protected.

countries.title: Which countries are covered by Regulation EC 261?

countries.p4: And you don't need to be an EU citizen to claim compensation: Regulation EC 261 applies to all passengers, regardless of nationality!

moral.p1: Brazilian courts frequently award compensation for the stress and inconvenience caused by cancelled or delayed flights. The amount can vary significantly depending on the impact on your life.

essentiel.title: What is the Montreal Convention?
essentiel.p1: The Montreal Convention is an international treaty that governs airline liability in cases of delay, death, or injury of passengers, as well as for baggage damages on international flights.
